newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Bankers Trust to manage funds in Singapore.
newsitem.headline: Bankers Trust to manage funds in Singapore.

text.p: Bankers Trust has opened a Singapore fund management office managing a S$500 million (US$354.6 million) account for Southeast Asia, the company said on Monday.

Ian Martin, Bankers Trust's global head of investment management, told a press conference that Bankers Trust Funds Management (Singapore) (BTFMS) would play "a pivotal role in our investment management process".
The S$500 million portfolio is about 40 per cent of the group's Southeast Asian portfolio, excluding Japan, and was previously managed out of Sydney.

"It is assuming responsibility within the group for investing S$500 million, of which S$400 million is sourced from foreign investors and a further S$100 million is sourced from local investors," said Martin.
Liberalisation, deregulation, prospects for retail fund management growth and Singapore's role as a regional financial centre were key reasons for the Singapore office, he said.
The prospect of managing funds from Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) was also among the attractions.
"We see great opportunities in Singapore's funds management business," said BTFMS managing director and chief executive officer Lee Tiong Seng.
Bankers Trust had begun talks with the authorities but there had been no formal submission on the CPF issue, he said.
Among the issues being discussed was the requirement of a three-year track record for fund management companies in Singapore before they can manage CPF funds.
BTFMS was "hopeful of a successful outcome", said Lee.
